docs.lead_paragraph: JENSEN--Camille McLean Anderson. Died on December 18 of natural causes at her residence in Darien, Connecticut. She was 95. Camille was born on December 14, 1919, in Holly Springs, Mississippi, the daughter of Percy Harmon and Camille McLean Anderson. She attended Miss Hutchison's School in Memphis and graduated from Mary Baldwin College in Staunton, Virginia, in 1941. In 1942 she was named Maid of Cotton at the Memphis Cotton Carnival by the National Cotton Council. She married Frode Jensen, a physician, in 1948 and settled in Denver, Colorado. In 1950 they moved to Riverdale, New York, where she participated in the Parent Teachers Association at the Riverdale Country School, was a founding member of the Board of the Wave Hill Association, served on the board of the Girl Scouts Association of Greater New York, was a founder of the Riverdale Presbyterian Church Nursery School, and was a member of the board of governors of the Riverdale Yacht Club. On weekends she and Frode enjoyed their country home at the Gipsy Trail Club in Carmel, New York. After her husband's death in 1973, Camille enjoyed a successful career as a realtor in Riverdale with Robert E. Hill, Inc. In 1987, she retired and moved to New Canaan, Connecticut, where she lived for 25 years. Camille was predeceased by her husband, Frode, and is survived by her three children; her son, Frode (Skip) and his wife, Kitty, of Park City, Utah, her daughter Camille, of Manhattan, and her son, Peter, of Phoenixville, Pennsylvania. She is also survived by her five grandchildren: Christian McLean, Catherine Spotswood Hall, and Henry Carter Jensen; and Matthew St. John and Alexander Jensen Douglas. Funeral arrangements are being handled by Edward Lawrence Funeral Home in Darien, CT. Funeral services will be private. Camille will be interred in the Hamilton College Cemetery. A memorial service next spring is planned in Clinton, NY. Contributions in Camille's memory can be made to the Frode and Camille Jensen Scholarship Fund at Hamilton College, 198 College Hill Road, Clinton, NY 13323.

docs.lead_paragraph: There is little doubt that the Peshawar massacre has galvanized Pakistani society. The question is whether it can become a real turning point for a society plagued by violent divisions, culture wars and the strategic prerogatives of a powerful military.

byline.contributor: Salman Masood contributed reporting from Islamabad, Pakistan, and Saba Imtiaz from Karachi, Pakistan.

docs.abstract: News analysis; mass killing of at least 132 Pakistani schoolchildren by Taliban gunmen has, for the first time, united Pakistani society against the Taliban; Pakistanis from across the country are speaking out forcefully against militant threat and religious parties and ultraconservative politicians are publicly shunning Taliban; demonstrations have so far been small but widespread.
